entry.title: How you can manage polish KSeF Requirement in SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA
entry.content:
In my last Blogpost I introduced you into How Official Document Numbering helps to fulfil the Polish KSeF Requirements in S4HANA Public Cloud.

 

The aim of this new Blog is to give you a concrete example, how the new ODN Framework can help customers having business in Poland to fulfill the new legal requirement of KSeF (Dz.U. 2023 poz. 1598) with SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA.

 

The alternative Solution for SAP ERP can be found in those two Notes:

  • 3423256 - ECC Only : KSeF number enablement for FI postings and line item reports - SAP for Me
  • 3451944 - KSeF number enablement for MIRO postings - SAP for Me

 

 Process Overview

  • For the Outbound Process of Sales Invoices, the following process flow is applicable:

 

  • For the Inbound Process of Vendor Invoices, the following process flows as follows:

 

 

 

Configuration

1.  Maintain Official Document Number Types - Transaction: “ODNTYP”

 

Create the ODN Types (Examples):

  • ZKSeF - Poland B2B KSeF reference number

 

 

 

2.  Map Official Document Number Type to Internal Type
- Transaction: “ODNINTTYP”

 

Map your custom official document number type to the SAP-delivered internal official document number type so that the system can correctly derive the official document number within your consuming application.

Procedure

  • In your configuration environment, search for and open the Map Official Document Number Type to Internal Type activity.
  • In the ODN Country/Region field, type PL and choose Apply.
  • Choose New Entries.
  • In the ODN Internal Type field, choose the SAP-delivered internal official document number type PLKSEF
  • In the ODN Type field, choose your custom official document number type; for example, ZKSEF
  • Save your changes.

 

 

3.  Configure Official Document Number Type Characteristics TA: “ODNTYPC”

 

Set the properties of your custom official document number type, such as its length and how it is processed.

 

Procedure

  • In your configuration environment, search for and open the Configure Official Document Number Type Characteristics activity.
  • In the ODN Country/Region field, type PL and choose Apply.
  • In the Assign Official Document Number Types to Country step, choose New Entries and add your custom official document number types from above.
  • Choose the new entry you have added for your custom official document number type and then go to User Interface Settings.
  • In the ODN Length field, enter the length as 35.
  • In the Legal Timestamp field, choose Generic Format as we want to enable legal timestamp.
  • Go to Process Specific Settings.
  • Choose New Entries and add the following entry:
    • For ZKSEF:

 

 

 

  • FI_CUSTOMER_INV:

 

  • MM_SUPPLIER_INV:

 

  • SD_BILLING_HEADER:

Save your changes.

 

Example – Supplier Invoice via transaction MIRO

 

  • Enter the invoice relevant data and then press “Additional Fiscal Data”

 

 

  • Now Enter the Official Document Numbers relevant for your transactions in Poland (KSeF):

 

 

 

Example – Customer Invoice via KSeF Portal

 

  • Submit and receive the Billing Invoice via EDocument Cockpit

 

  • The KSeF Number will be visible on the Billing Document Header itself:

 

 

 

More information

The Business Processes and SAP Help Documentation for ODN Numbers in Poland can be found here:

Business Area

Supported Business Processes

Description

Document and Reporting Compliance

Customer invoices exchanged using Document and Reporting Compliance

The system records the KSeF reference number assigned by the tax authorities to customer invoices exchanged using Document and Reporting Compliance.

Sourcing and Procurement

Supplier invoices in Sourcing and Procurement

You can manually maintain the official document number in supplier invoices. The system validates this value based on the properties maintained in the configuration.

 

Data Access via CDS Views:

Process

CDS View

SD Billing

I_BillingDocumentODN

FI Customer/Supplier invoice

I_AccountingDocumentODN

MM Supplier Invoice

I_SupplierInvoiceODN

 

 

 

Availability of the solution

 

The solution shown before is available for SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA Versions 1709 – 2025.

In general, there are two ways of consuming the solution.

  1. You can install the next feature Package for your S/4HANA Solution
  2. You can install the notes which have been released recently:
    • In this case refer to the note collection in SAP Note 3565339 for additional details and please also check the prerequisites carefully!

 

Important:

Please note that you also need to implement a DRC Note to have direct integration with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to sync the KSeF Number from Tax Portal towards your business documents.

This note will be available very soon.

 

I hope that I was able to provide you a good overview about how use the new ODN Framework to manage the Polish KSeF Requirement in SAP S/⁠4HANA Cloud Private Edition & SAP S/⁠4HANA

 

Thanks and see you next time!

 

Christian Seelinger

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Warsaw 2025
entry.content:
I'm excited to announce that SAP Inside Track Warsaw is coming back on 20 September 2025! This community-driven event is a great opportunity to share experiences, learn from experts, and network with fellow SAP professionals.

Date: 20 September 2025
Location: KMD Poland, Inflancka 4a, Warsaw

Important: Registration is only possible via our official landing page: https://event.kmd.dk/sapinsidetrackwarsaw

One day earlier — on 19 September 2025 — we will host an SAP Code Jam:  

SAP CodeJam ABAP Cloud (Warsaw, Poland) - SAP Community

We are preparing an exciting agenda covering topics such as:

  • ABAP Cloud and Clean Core concepts

  • SAP BTP innovations and best practices

  • SAP Integration Suite

  • SAP Analytics Cloud real-life use cases

  • Fiori elements and UI5 development tips

  • Customer success stories and project experiences

…and much more, all delivered by passionate community speakers!

Come, connect, and be part of the SAP community spirit in Warsaw!

entry.title: Re: Email is not getting triggered for suser id
entry.content:
After reviewing the details, I can confirm that the provided email ID appears to be in good standing and functioning as expected. Since the S-user S0027278955 is already linked to an SAP Universal ID 'shrenik@stellium.com' , to reset the SAP Universal ID, please follow the steps below: 

  1. Go to SAP for Me: https://me.sap.com and if not signed in, click Sign In top right 
  2. Enter the UID e-mail address and click Continue
  3. Click Forgot password?
  4. A reset link will be sent to the email ID 
  5. When the user receive the e-mail, click the Reset your password link or copy the provided link and paste into a browser
  6. Create a new password and make sure that the password has a minimum of 8 characters and includes 3 of the following:
    • Lowercase letters
    • Uppercase letters
    • Number [0-9]
    • Symbols [!@#^&*()+_,.{}?-]
  7. Click Save
  8. The user will receive a confirmation e-mail 

For additional details, you can refer to KBA 2882938 - How to reset or change SAP Universal ID (UID) password

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: ローカルのCAP Javaプロジェクトからリモート OData API へ接続する手順
entry.content:
目的

ローカルの CAP Java プロジェクトから、SAP S/4HANA の Sandbox OData API を呼び出してデータを取得する手順の一例をまとめます。最終的には、以下のURLにアクセスしてBusiness Partnersを取得することをゴールとします。

http://localhost:8080/odata/v4/BusinessPartnerService/BusinessPartner 

1. 検証時の環境

  •  SAP BTP トライアル環境

  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub の Sandbox 環境
  • 開発環境: Visual Studio Code 
  • Maven  3.9
  • OpenJDK 21

2. プロジェクトの作成

2.1. CAP Javaプロジェクトの初期化

cds init cap-java-remote-api --add destination,xsuaa --java

初期化後、以下のようなプロジェクトフォルダーが作成されます。

2.2. プロジェクトをVisual Studio Code で開く

code cap-java-remote-api

3. ライブラリの追加

リモート OData API に接続するには、SAP Cloud SDK と リモート OData用のライブラリが必要です。

3.1. ルートディレクトリのpom.xml に SAP Cloud SDK の最新のバージョンをプロパティとして追加し、dependencyManagement に sdk-bom を追加します。

<properties>
    ...
    <!-- 最新のSDKのバージョンに置き換える -->
    <cloud-sdk.version>5.20.0</cloud-sdk.version>
</properties>
...
<dependencyManagement>
	<dependencies>
        ...
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.sap.cloud.sdk</groupId>
            <artifactId>sdk-bom</artifactId>
            <version>${cloud-sdk.version}</version>
            <type>pom</type>
            <scope>import</scope>
        </dependency>
	</dependencies>
</dependencyManagement>

3.2. srv/pom.xmlに以下のライブラリを追加します。

<dependencies>
    ...
    <dependency>
		<groupId>com.sap.cds</groupId>
		<artifactId>cds-feature-remote-odata</artifactId>
		<scope>runtime</scope>
	</dependency>

	<dependency>
		<groupId>com.sap.cloud.sdk</groupId>
		<artifactId>sdk-core</artifactId>
	</dependency>
</dependencies>

4. ODataメタデータの取得とCSNの生成

OData API を使うには、ODataのエンティティやプロパティ情報を記載したメタデータファイル(EDMX)から、CAP内部の共通モデル表現として役割を果たす、CSN形式に変換した上で、CDSでのモデリングを行う必要があります。

4.1. SAP Business Accelerator HubのBusiness Partner (A2X)からEDMXをダウンロード

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/overview

4.2. ルートディレクトリの配下に.edmxファイルを格納

4.3. .edmxから.csn を生成

cds import API_BUSINESS_PARTNER.edmx

実行後、 srv/external フォルダに .edmx と .csn ファイルが生成されます。 

加えて、application.yaml に Destination Service のテンプレート設定が追加されます。

5. 接続設定

S/4HANA のような外部システムと接続する際に、他サービスからの再利用性も高く、接続先や認証情報を設定できるBTP の Destination Service を利用します。今回はSandbox 環境のため、APIKeyでの認証を行い、.envファイルにその情報を格納しますが、実運用環境では他の適切な認証方式を使用してください。

5.1. BTP Destination Service に S/4HANA Sandbox の情報を登録

  • Name: S4Sandbox
  • Type: HTTP
  • ProxyType: Internet
  • URL: https://sandbox.api.sap.com/s4hanacloud
  • Authentication: NoAuthentication
    • Sandbox環境のため、ここではNoAuthenticationを選択し、後続のapplication.yamlにてAPIKeyを.env経由で渡します。

5.2. .envにAPIKeyを設定

APIキーはBusiness Accelerator Hubから取得できます。

APIKey=<Business Accelerator Hubで取得したAPIキー>

5.3. application.yamlで接続先の設定

cds:
  remote:
    services:
      API_BUSINESS_PARTNER:
        destination:
          # 対象のDestination Serviceで登録したDestination名を記載する
          name: S4Sandbox
        http:
          suffix: /sap/opu/odata/sap
          # Sandbox APIを使用する場合には、APIKeyをHTTPヘッダーに入れる必要がある
          headers:
            # 環境変数のAPIKeyを参照する
            APIKey: ${APIKey}
        type: odata-v2

6. サービスモデルとハンドラの実装

6.1 srv/business-partner-service.cdsにサービスモデルを実装

using {API_BUSINESS_PARTNER as bp} from './external/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER';

service BusinessPartnerService @(requires: 'any') {
    entity BusinessPartner as projection on bp.A_BusinessPartner {
        key A_BusinessPartner.BusinessPartner,
            A_BusinessPartner.BusinessPartnerName,
            A_BusinessPartner.BusinessPartnerFullName
    };
}

先ほど作成した .csn に含まれる API_BUSINESS_PARTNER を投影し、サービスモデルのエンティティ BusinessPartner を定義します。

6.2. srv/src/main/java/customer/cap_java_remote_api/handlers/BusinessPartnerHandler.javaにハンドラを実装

package customer.cap_java_remote_api.handlers;

import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;

import com.sap.cds.Result;
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CdsReadEventContext;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.On;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName;

import cds.gen.api_business_partner.ApiBusinessPartner;
import cds.gen.businesspartnerservice.BusinessPartner_;
import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;

@Component
@ServiceName("BusinessPartnerService")
public class BusinessPartnerHandler implements EventHandler {

    @Autowired
    ApiBusinessPartner remoteBp;

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(BusinessPartnerHandler.class);
    // このブログサービスの仕様でアットマークとそれに付随する文字列が消えてしまいます。下記のコードに置き換えてください。
    (entity = BusinessPartner_.CDS_NAME)
    public Result readBusinessPartner(CdsReadEventContext context) {
        try {
            logger.info("Reading Business Partner data from S/4HANA with CQN: {}", context.getCqn());
            return remoteBp.run(context.getCqn());
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.error("Error while reading Business Partner data from S/4HANA.", e);
            throw new RuntimeException(e);
        }
    }
}

上記でコメントした行をこちらに置き換えてください。

'@On(entity = BusinessPartner_.CDS_NAME)'

また、CQNを使用する際は、CqnServiceを継承したインターフェイスを使用します。今回でいうと、remoteBpのインターフェイスであるApiBusinessPartnerは、CqnServiceを継承しています。

7. デプロイ準備

ローカルで開発したCAP JavaアプリケーションをSAP BTPのCloud Foundry環境へデプロイするための準備を行います。

7.1. MTAファイルの作成

cds add mta

mta.yamlが生成されますが、modulesに記載のcap-java-remote-api-srvが生成されただけではなく、プロジェクト初期化の際にaddオプションでつけた、xsuaaとdestinationがそれぞれバッキングサービスとしてresourcesに記載されていることが確認できます。

加えて、srv/pom.xmlに以下のライブラリが追加されます。

<dependencies>
    ...
    <dependency>
		<groupId>com.sap.cds</groupId>
		<artifactId>cds-starter-cloudfoundry</artifactId>
		<scope>runtime</scope>
	</dependency>

	<dependency>
		<groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
		<artifactId>spring-boot-starter-actuator</artifactId>
	</dependency>
</dependencies>

7.2. ビルド&ローカルリポジトリへのインストール

mvn clean install

8. BTPへデプロイ

8.1. mtarファイルの作成

mbt build --mtar archive
#  CAPを扱う際には、前回のビルド成果物を削除したいケースが多いので、
# 下記のコマンドを叩くことが多いです。
# rm -rf mta_archives && mbt build --mtar archive

8.2. 対象のCloud Foundry環境を選択

BTP CockpitのサブアカウントページからAPI Endpointを取得できます。

cf api <対象のCFエンドポイント>

8.3. Cloud Foundryにログイン

cf login

8.4. Cloud Foundryにデプロイ

cf deploy mta_archives/archive.mtar
# デプロイが失敗した時には三度のリトライがデフォルトで実施されますが、
# 一度だけで済ませても問題ないケースが多いので、時間短縮のために、下記のコマンドをよく使います。
# cf deploy mta_archives/archive.mtar --retries 1

 8.5. BTP Cockpitでデプロイ結果を確認

9. ローカルからリモートAPIへアクセス

最後に、ローカル環境からリモートOData APIにアクセスします。そのためには、BTPにデプロイしたバッキングサービスをローカルにバインドする必要があります。

9.1. BTP上のxsuaaとdestinationをローカルにバインド

cds bind auth --to cap-java-remote-api-auth
cds bind destination --to cap-java-remote-api-destination

このバインドにより、ハイブリッド環境用のバッキングサービスの設定が行えます。

9.2. Hybrid Testing

cds bind --exec -- mvn spring-boot:run

9.3. 対象エンドポイントにて、結果を確認

http://localhost:8080/odata/v4/BusinessPartnerService/BusinessPartner

CAP Javaプロジェクトのお役に立てれば幸いです！

entry.title: How to Call a Remote OData API from Your Local CAP Java Project
entry.content:
Objective

This post walks you through how to call the SAP S/4HANA sandbox OData API from a local CAP Java project.
The final goal is to call the following endpoint and retrieve a list of business partners:
http://localhost:8080/odata/v4/BusinessPartnerService/BusinessPartner

1. Testing Environment

  • SAP BTP Trial
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub – Sandbox
  • IDE: Visual Studio Code
  • Maven 3.9
  • OpenJDK 21

2. Project Setup

2.1 Initialize a CAP Java project

cds init cap-java-remote-api --add destination,xsuaa --java

The command creates the following folder structure:

2.2 Open the project in VS Code

code cap-java-remote-api

3. Add Required Libraries

To call a remote OData service you need both the SAP Cloud SDK and the CAP library for remote OData.

3.1 Add the  latest SDK version to the properties and the Cloud SDK BOM to the root pom.xml

<properties>
    ...
    <!-- Replace with the latest SDK version -->
    <cloud-sdk.version>5.20.0</cloud-sdk.version>
</properties>
...
<dependencyManagement>
	<dependencies>
        ...
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.sap.cloud.sdk</groupId>
            <artifactId>sdk-bom</artifactId>
            <version>${cloud-sdk.version}</version>
            <type>pom</type>
            <scope>import</scope>
        </dependency>
	</dependencies>
</dependencyManagement>

3.2 Add the following dependencies to srv/pom.xml

<dependencies>
    ...
    <dependency>
		<groupId>com.sap.cds</groupId>
		<artifactId>cds-feature-remote-odata</artifactId>
		<scope>runtime</scope>
	</dependency>

	<dependency>
		<groupId>com.sap.cloud.sdk</groupId>
		<artifactId>sdk-core</artifactId>
	</dependency>
</dependencies>

4. Fetch OData Metadata and Generate CSN

CAP needs a CSN file, so you must first download the EDMX file and convert it.

4.1 Download the Business Partner (A2X) EDMX from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub
https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/overview

4.2 Place the .edmx file in the project’s root folder.

4.3 Generate a .csn file from the .edmx

cds import API_BUSINESS_PARTNER.edmx

After execution, both the .edmx and .csn files appear in srv/external.

A template for the Destination Service is also added to application.yaml.

5. Connectivity Configuration

You will use the BTP Destination Service to store the connectivity settings such as the URL and authentication. Because you are calling the sandbox, authentication is done via an API Key stored in a local .env file. In a productive scenario you would switch to a more secure authentication method.

5.1 Create a destination in BTP

  • Name: S4Sandbox
  • Type: HTTP
  • ProxyType: Internet
  • URL: https://sandbox.api.sap.com/s4hanacloud
  • Authentication: NoAuthentication

5.2 Store the API Key in .env

You can get the API Key on Business Accelerator Hub.

APIKey=<your-API-key-from-Business-Accelerator-Hub>

5.3 Configure the destination in application.yaml

cds:
  remote:
    services:
      API_BUSINESS_PARTNER:
        destination:
          # Name of the destination you just created
          name: S4Sandbox
        http:
          suffix: /sap/opu/odata/sap
          # The sandbox requires the API Key in a header
          headers:
            # Read from the env file
            APIKey: ${APIKey}
        type: odata-v2

6. Service Model and Handler

6.1 Define the service model in srv/business-partner-service.cds

using {API_BUSINESS_PARTNER as bp} from './external/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER';

service BusinessPartnerService @(requires: 'any') {
    entity BusinessPartner as projection on bp.A_BusinessPartner {
        key A_BusinessPartner.BusinessPartner,
            A_BusinessPartner.BusinessPartnerName,
            A_BusinessPartner.BusinessPartnerFullName
    };
}

Project the API_BUSINESS_PARTNER definition from the .csn file you just created and use it to define the BusinessPartner entity in your service model.

6.2 Implement the handler in
srv/src/main/java/customer/cap_java_remote_api/handlers/BusinessPartnerHandler.java

package customer.cap_java_remote_api.handlers;

import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Component;

import com.sap.cds.Result;
import com.sap.cds.services.cds.CdsReadEventContext;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.EventHandler;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.On;
import com.sap.cds.services.handler.annotations.ServiceName;

import cds.gen.api_business_partner.ApiBusinessPartner;
import cds.gen.businesspartnerservice.BusinessPartner_;
import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;

@Component
@ServiceName("BusinessPartnerService")
public class BusinessPartnerHandler implements EventHandler {

    @Autowired
    ApiBusinessPartner remoteBp;

    private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(BusinessPartnerHandler.class);
    // This blogging platform strips out the “@” symbol and 'On' that follows it, so please replace the above line with the code shown below.
    (entity = BusinessPartner_.CDS_NAME)
    public Result readBusinessPartner(CdsReadEventContext context) {
        try {
            logger.info("Reading Business Partner data from S/4HANA with CQN: {}", context.getCqn());
            return remoteBp.run(context.getCqn());
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.error("Error while reading Business Partner data from S/4HANA.", e);
            throw new RuntimeException(e);
        }
    }
}

Please replace the commented line above with the following code:

'@On(entity = BusinessPartner_.CDS_NAME)'

When you work with CQN, use an interface that extends CqnService. In this case, the interface for remoteBp, ApiBusinessPartner, does exactly that: it extends CqnService.

7. Prepare for Deployment

7.1 Generate an MTA descriptor

cds add mta

The generated mta.yaml now contains a module (cap-java-remote-api-srv) and the backing services (xsuaa, destination) that you added during init.

The following dependencies are also auto-added to srv/pom.xml:

<dependencies>
    ...
    <dependency>
		<groupId>com.sap.cds</groupId>
		<artifactId>cds-starter-cloudfoundry</artifactId>
		<scope>runtime</scope>
	</dependency>

	<dependency>
		<groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
		<artifactId>spring-boot-starter-actuator</artifactId>
	</dependency>
</dependencies>

7.2 Build the project and install to your local Maven repo

mvn clean install

8. Deploy to BTP

8.1 Create an .mtar file

mbt build --mtar archive
# It is often useful to clean old artifacts:
# rm -rf mta_archives && mbt build --mtar archive

8.2 Target the correct Cloud Foundry org/space

You can obtain the targeted Endpoint from the BTP Cockpit:

cf api <your Cloud Foundry endpoint>

8.3 Log in to Cloud Foundry

cf login

8.4 Deploy to Cloud Foundry

cf deploy mta_archives/archive.mtar
# Skip the default 3 retries to save time:
# cf deploy mta_archives/archive.mtar --retries 1

8.5 Verify the deployment in the BTP Cockpit

9. Access the Remote API from Your Local Environment

Because the backing services live on BTP, you need to bind them locally for hybrid testing.

9.1 Bind xsuaa and destination locally

cds bind auth --to cap-java-remote-api-auth
cds bind destination --to cap-java-remote-api-destination

9.2 Run the application in hybrid mode

cds bind --exec -- mvn spring-boot:run

9.3 Open the endpoint

http://localhost:8080/odata/v4/BusinessPartnerService/BusinessPartner

You should now see the list of business partners fetched from the SAP S/4HANA sandbox.

I hope this helps you kick-start your CAP Java project!

entry.title: Re: DB2 11.5 LUW - HADR rebuild from online backup ?
entry.content:
Hello Brian, you can start the HADR pair as soon as the restore on the standby has been finished and the HADR-related configuration (like local host, remote host, ...) has been done.
The standby will then start performing  the remote catchup and the primary will get any needed log files from its archive to provide them to the standby for rollforward.

It is best practice to set up the same log archiving location (aka shared archive) for both the primary as well as the standby anyhow, being accessible by both the primary and the standby.
If you have different locations, in case of a HADR failover, archived log files of the former standby / new primary will go to this different location then.  And, as you can imagine, with several failovers forth and back, you will have a mixture of archived logs in different locations which may need manual intervention in case of recovery.
Link to relevant documentation: https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/db2/11.5.x?topic=hadr-log-archiving-configuration

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Frequently Asked Questions
entry.content:
Hint: A separate blog post with all questions regarding partner topics will be published in the near future. The corresponding link will be added after its publication.

The content of this blog post will be continuously updated, and additional questions will be added.

Overview SAP BTP ABAP Environment

What is the SAP BTP ABAP Environment?

SAP BTP ABAP Environment is the platform as a service for ABAP developers. It’s a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud apps.

What is ABAP Cloud and why is it needed?

ABAP Cloud is specifically tailored to the needs of cloud development. ABAP Cloud is the new, modern approach to making ABAP development future-proof and cloud-ready. It is the ABAP development model for creating cloud-ready business apps, services, and extensions. It combines various cloud technologies for development, including ABAP Core Data Services (CDS) for data modeling, the ABAP RESTful application programming model (RAP), SAP Fiori UI technology, and the ABAP Development Tools (ADT). It maintains a strict separation between SAP, customer, and partner coding.

It is the necessary path for all extensions in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud environment and is also becoming increasingly important for on-premise systems. All cloud development must be implemented with ABAP Cloud; classic ABAP is not permitted in cloud applications.

 

Use cases

What are typical use cases?

The platform offers the possibility for a variety of individual solutions; the following list contains the most prominent examples.

  • Loosely coupled side-by-side extensions and applications
  • Tightly coupled on-stack extensions
  • Hub-like usage for integration scenarios
  • Partners can provide Multitenant SaaS solutions and the partner Add-on product
Who can use it?

The environment can be used for different target groups, with respective features and use cases.

For education:

  • Learn ABAP Cloud and evaluate the SAP BTP ABAP Environment
  • Try it out using the Trial Account or the Free Tier Option
  • Free Tier systems can be smoothly converted into a standard system

For customer:

  • Develop and run loosely coupled side-by-side extensions for example for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Develop tightly coupled on-stack extensions

For partners:

  • Develop and run multitenancy-enabled SaaS applications for their customers
  • Develop and provide a partner Add-on product for customers

Of course, the SAP BTP ABAP Environment is also used for internal scenarios, so that our own products run on it.

 

Benefits

What are the key benefits?
  • Extend SAP applications: Use the side-by-side approach to develop and run custom extensions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Accelerate cloud transformation: Reuse ABAP assets and knowledge to build breakthrough innovations in the cloud
  • Keep the core clean: Transform on-premise custom code to a separate platform to decouple it from the digital core and profit from independent release cycles
How can the environment be used in relation to clean core?

The SAP BTP ABAP Environment supports the concept of the clean core in several ways to ensure the maintainability, scalability, and long-term sustainability of ABAP-based solutions. Due to the enforced use of ABAP Cloud, the development is 100% clean core by default.

Some aspects are listed here:

  • Cloud-native development: The SAP BTP ABAP Environment enables developers to create cloud-native ABAP applications that can extend classic systems.
  • Side-by-Side Extensions: Using side-by-side extensions, customers can develop and deploy custom extensions outside of the core system. This minimizes the risk of disruptions caused by customizations in the core system and facilitates updates and upgrades.
  • Use of APIs and services: SAP BTP ABAP Environment supports an API-driven development approach, where applications communicate with other SAP systems via well-defined interfaces. There is also the option to use reuse services.
  • Update and upgrade stability: The SAP BTP ABAP Environment ensures that customer-specific customizations and extensions are separated from the core system, increasing stability during updates and upgrades. This minimizes the risk of conflicts and instability and enables regular updates and patches without impacting core processes.

Further information on Clean Core and Extensibility can be found in the Extensibility Guide.

Are there any AI features which can be used with the SAP BTP ABAP Environment?

It is possible to use the SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities. These include various features to support developers, for example, the unit test generation, the BO generator or the code completion. These features can be used in Eclipse together with the ABAP Development Tools (ADT). The AI features are part of a separate contract.

 

Tools and Development

Which tools and development IDEs are available for ABAP development in the cloud?

The clear recommendation is to use Eclipse together with ADT. In the SAP Business Application Studio, changes to the UI can be made if necessary. An introduction on how to connect the two systems can be found on this SAP Help Page.

Where can I find resources and tutorials for development?

There are various materials and tutorials available to help you get started with ABAP Cloud. The following are good starting points:

  • Development Tutorials on GitHub
  • Learning Journey: Practicing Clean Core Extensibility For SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Learning Journey: Acquiring Core ABAP Skills
  • SAP Certified Associate: Back-End Developer - ABAP Cloud
  • SAP Help Portal: Tutorials for ABAP Cloud

What tools are available for lifecycle management?

There are various tools for lifecycle management

One is abapGit: This is used to transport development objects into SAP BTP ABAP instances. Its use as a transport system is not recommended. Furthermore, there is the git-enabled change and transport system (gCTS), which is used to transport objects between the dev and test systems. More information regarding gCTS can be found in this blog post in the SAP Community. It's also possible to use the existing Git within the company using the Bring-Your-Own-Git (BYOG) feature.

The SAP Landscape Portal acts as a central tool to allow service providers to perform administration tasks such as hibernating systems, creating test tenants and support users, selecting systems for a pre-upgrade, but also lifecycle management operations such as building, deploying and updating product versions, and even guides you through the configuration and deployment of multitenant SaaS solutions.

 

System Management and Administration

How does the standard sizing look like?

The system consists of two components: the runtime, called ABAP Compute Unit (ACU), and the persistence, called HANA Compute Unit (HCU). The minimum system size includes one ACU and two HCUs. We recommend starting with this configuration; later adjustments are possible at any time. Even one ACU is very powerful and can serve 1,000 business users in a single day.

How can the systems be managed and administered?

General system configuration, such as setting up systems, adjusting metrics, and creating subaccounts, is performed via the SAP BTP Cockpit. Further specific system management is performed via the SAP Landscape Portal, which is included with every system and is free to use. This allows for a wide variety of administrative and configuration tasks, such as user and role management, system hibernation, and application deployment.

How can the system size be adjusted?

The system size can be adjusted manually via the SAP BTP Cockpit. This applies to both ACUs and HCUs. The customer and partner can make the size adjustment themselves and independently. Furthermore, there is the possibility to use system hibernation and elastic scaling, more on this in the next section.

Will the system upgrades cause downtime for my systems?

Standard upgrades require a planned downtime of the systems. The downtimes are covered by contractual SLAs and the schedule is announced in advance for the whole calendar year (see this blog post). A down-time optimized approach is in place for productive systems. The required technical downtime will be reduced in further releases. The individual phases of the upgrade are described in this blog post in the SAP Community.

Does the entire system landscape have to be created right at the beginning?

No, we recommend setting up the systems when they are needed. This reduces complexity at the beginning, and you only pay for the systems you need at that moment. To begin, either the Free Tier system can be converted, or a new development system can be created in the SAP BTP Cockpit. Development can then take place there and all transports can be released. Next, the test system is created with the software component on which the development is based. Finally, the production system can be created. This way, the three system landscape is built piece by piece based on the requirements. If systems are not in use, they can be shut down using system hibernation to save costs.

What are the recommendations for setting up subaccounts in the SAP BTP Cockpit?

We recommend creating a separate subaccount for each system. This provides maximum flexibility regarding trust settings, which are always defined at the subaccount level. Of course, there are other development scenarios where multiple systems per subaccount would be helpful. However, we generally recommend one system per subaccount.

 

Hosting and Data Center

Which hyperscalers are available to host the systems?

There are currently three different providers to choose from: Amazon Web Services (AWS), Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud. Furthermore, the option to use SAP as a hyperscaler will be added this year, so no external service provider is required. An overview of the hyperscalers can also be found in the SAP Discovery Center.

In which data centers can the systems be located?

The data centers are distributed globally and can be found in a wide variety of countries. EU access, for example, can also be granted. A complete list of all locations is available in the SAP Discovery Center.

Can a synchronous replication be created as a backup from the SAP BTP ABAP Environment system?

Starting in Q4/2025, it will be possible to create a so-called availability zone in which the system is replicated, more information in this blog post in the SAP Community. This functionality is part of the in-metro disaster recovery feature of the SAP BTP. This occurs in the same data center region as the original system. Mirroring in a different region is not possible.

 

Licensing and Costs

How can the SAP BTP ABAP Environment be licensed and how much does it cost?

There are different licensing options, both subscription-based and consumption-based. An overview can be found in the following table or in the SAP Discovery Center. 

LicenseMaterial CodeService NameMetricBlock SizeMin. BlocksPrice block/ h
Pay-as-you-go8017640SAP BTP ABAP environment, runtimeGB memory16 GB12.50€/ hour
Pay-as-you-go8017640SAP BTP ABAP environment, persistenceGB memory16 GB20.71€/ hour
SAP BTPEA & CPEA8016044 (BTPEA), 8005605 (CPEA)SAP BTP ABAP environment, runtimeGB memory16 GB11.92€/ hour
SAP BTPEA & CPEA8016044 (BTPEA), 8005605 (CPEA)SAP BTP ABAP environment, persistenceGB memory16 GB2 0.55€/ hour
Is there an option to try out the SAP BTP ABAP Environment?

Yes, there are two options. One is using the Trial Account with a shared instance, and the other is using the Free Tier Option with a private instance. Both options are time-limited; all information can be found in this dedicated blog post in the SAP Community.

Is the SAP BTP ABAP Environment part of SAP Build?

Yes, the SAP BTP ABAP Environment is part of SAP Build since Q3/2024. The ABAP Runtime can also be purchased with the SAP Build SKU 8019321. This is implemented in the form of a subscription model based on capacity units; there is no consumption-based variant. There is no technical difference to the well-established service plan standard.

LicenseMaterial CodeService NameMetricBlock SizeMin. BlocksPrice block/ h
SAP Build Runtime8019321SAP BTP ABAP environment, runtimeGB memory16 GB11.92€/ hour
SAP Build Runtime8019321SAP BTP ABAP environment, persistenceGB memory16 GB2 0.55€/ hour
How can I switch from a standard contract to the SAP Build SKU?

Switching to the Build Runtime SKU is quite simple. It simply involves changing the service plan. This service plan must be changed in the SAP BTP Cockpit, which the customer can do themselves. The change has no impact on the system, which will remain as before, and nothing needs to be adjusted. There will be no downtime or anything similar.

Are there opportunities to optimize costs?

There is the possibility to use the functionality of system hibernation, more information in this blog post in the SAP Community. This feature makes it possible to shut down development systems at a specific time when they are not needed. For example, the system can be shut down over the weekend. During this time, the costs for the ACU are waived and for the HCUs only 12.5% of the original costs must be paid.

The manual adjustment of the ACUs and HCUs is quite static and cannot vary automatically according to the runtime. For this case, there is elastic scaling. The system continuously monitors utilization metrics and adjusts the number of application servers accordingly (up or down). This means customers only pay for actual usage, reducing costs while still ensuring sufficient capacity is available for peak loads when needed.

 

Release Cycle and Roadmap

In which cycle do the new releases come?

New releases are delivered quarterly (February, May, August, and November). New data center locations are added independently throughout the year.

Is it possible to try out the upcoming features before the actual upgrade?

With the pre-upgrade option, systems can receive the new functionality before the actual upgrade. This always takes place approximately two weeks before the actual upgrade. This option offers customers and partners a longer testing period. There are fixed maintenance and upgrade windows for both the upgrade and the pre-upgrade, which will be announced in advance.

Where can I find the external product roadmap?

The external product roadmap can be found in the SAP Roadmap Explorer. Additional information about the releases and the roadmap is available in the Release Navigator for SAP BTP.

entry.title: Re: Variant configuration- Separate Sales order line item
entry.content:
Yes, in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise 2022 FPS, you can configure your KMAT materials with Variant Configuration (LO-VC) to automatically trigger additional sales order lines based on selected characteristics—including sourcing from different plants and delivery dates. This requires a combination of BOM setup, configuration profile settings, and possibly user exits or dependencies.

You can use BOM explosion in sales orders to generate separate line items for subcomponents based on selected configuration options.

Maintain BOM with Usage = 5 (Sales & Distribution), Include subcomponents that may need to be delivered separately. Use selection conditions tied to characteristics (e.g., if Option A = Yes, include Component X).

Configure KMAT Material Profile via CU41. Go to Process → Sales Order (SET). Set BOM Explosion = SD01 (Single Level). Ensure Sales-Relevant Components are flagged.

Create preconditions or selection conditions to control which components are added based on chosen options. You can also use procedure dependencies to set plant or delivery date dynamically.

With the above settings, when the sales order is created and the KMAT is configured, SAP will automatically add relevant subcomponents as separate line items. You can assign different plants and delivery dates to these lines independently

entry.title: SAP Job Scheduling Service: Set Job Run Status with the REST API and Node.js
entry.content:
🚀 Introduction

Sometimes things go wrong. You’ve scheduled an asynchronous (long-running) background job using the SAP Job Scheduling Service on BTP, and your app endpoint was triggered. But something failed - maybe the app timed out, crashed, or didn’t properly call back to update the job status.

As a result, the job run is stuck in an ACK_RECEIVED state and will eventually go to UNKNOWN. This can cause confusion in your monitoring tools or delay in alert resolution.

This post shows how to manually override the status of a stuck job run by calling the SAP Job Scheduling Update Job Run Log REST API using Node.js.

For more cool Job Scheduling Service Blog Posts check the Overview page

🧠 Why Manual Overrides Are Needed

The SAP Job Scheduler supports both synchronous and asynchronous jobs. When the scheduler triggers an asynchronous job (like an HTTP endpoint), it expects your application to call back once it's completed and update the job run status using the API.

If this call doesn’t happen - for example, the app 💀 dies before responding - the scheduler doesn’t assume success or failure. The job remains in an intermediate state (ACK_RECEIVED) and might eventually be marked as UNKNOWN.

To fix this, we can manually call the scheduler’s REST API and set the run to FAILURE or SUCCESS.

🔧 Update Job Run Log API Overview

Endpoint:

PUT /scheduler/jobs/{jobId}/schedules/{scheduleId}/runs/{runId}
 

Sample request body:

{
  "success": false,
  "message": "Manually failed due to timeout or missing callback"
}
 

This call requires:

  • The Job ID, Schedule ID, and Run ID (must be known beforehand)
  • A valid OAuth token from your Job Scheduler service instance

When successful, the run’s status will be updated to FAILURE, and monitoring tools will reflect this immediately.

Creating service-keys

We need a service keys for the instances so that we can "talk" to the REST API. We can create these service keys either in the cockpit or using the CLI.

We can name it service-key, download it and place it in the same folder as the script.

 

 

The Code

package.json

{
  "name": "job-scheduling-service-rest-set-run-failed",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Used to manually set a job execution status to failed using the REST API",
  "main": "index.js",
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node index.js"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "axios": "^1.9.0",
    "qs": "^6.14.0"
  }
}
 

There are 4 simple steps in the script:

  1. 🔐 Load the Service Key
  2. 🔑 Authenticate via OAuth2
  3. 🛠️ Call the Update Job Run Log API
  4. 🚀 Run the Script

index.js

import fs from 'node:fs';
import axios from 'axios';
import qs from 'qs';

// 🔐 ========================= LOAD SERVICE KEY ========================= 🔐
const serviceKey = JSON.parse(
  fs.readFileSync("service-key.txt", "utf8")
);

// 🔑 ========================= AUTHENTICATION ============================ 🔑
async function getAccessToken(serviceKey) {
  const tokenUrl = `${serviceKey.uaa.url}/oauth/token`;
  const data = qs.stringify({
    grant_type: 'client_credentials',
    client_id: serviceKey.uaa.clientid,
    client_secret: serviceKey.uaa.clientsecret,
  });

  const response = await axios.post(tokenUrl, data, {
    headers: {
      'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded',
    },
  });

  return response.data.access_token;
}

// 🛠️ =========================  UPDATE JOB RUN STATUS ========================= 🛠️
async function updateJobRunStatus(token, serviceKey, jobId, scheduleId, runId) {
  // https://help.sap.com/docs/job-scheduling/sap-job-scheduling-service/update-job-run-log?locale=en-US
  const url = `${serviceKey.url}/scheduler/jobs/${jobId}/schedules/${scheduleId}/runs/${runId}`;

  const response = await axios.put(
    url,
    {
      success: false,
      message: "Manually failed due to stuck ACK_RECEIVED status",
    },
    {
      headers: {
        Authorization: `Bearer ${token}`,
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
      },
    }
  );

  console.log("✅ Job run status manually set to FAILED");
}

// 🚪 ========================= FULL WORKING EXAMPLE ========================= 🚪
async function main() {
  const serviceKey = JSON.parse(fs.readFileSync("service-key.txt", "utf8"));
  const token = await getAccessToken(serviceKey);

  const jobId = "<YOUR_JOB_ID>";
  const scheduleId = "<YOUR_SCHEDULE_ID>";
  const runId = "<YOUR_RUN_ID>";

  await updateJobRunStatus(token, serviceKey, jobId, scheduleId, runId);
}

// 🏁 ========================= START SCRIPT ============================== 🏁
main().catch(err => console.error("❌ Error:", err));

Run the script with:

npm install
node index.js

Result:

🔍 Optional: Verifying the Update

You can verify the run’s new status in the Job Scheduling service Dashboard or with the REST API.

⚠️ Best Practices

  • Only override runs if you’re certain the original job has failed or stalled.
  • Include a clear reason in the message field (useful for audits and logs).
  • Log each override operation in your own system.

📄 Summary

With just a few lines of Node.js, you can regain control over stuck asynchronous jobs in the SAP Job Scheduling service. By manually updating job run statuses, you ensure that your monitoring tools, logs, and workflows reflect the correct job state.

If you found this useful or have any questions, feel free to comment below!

Happy scheduling! 🚀

For more cool Job Scheduling Service Blog Posts check the Overview page

entry.title: Re: How to Find Accounting Documents Related to GR/IR For...
entry.content:
To extract GR/IR accounting documents specifically related to asset acquisition during MIGO, you’ll need more refined logic than just filtering by posting key 96 in FBL3N.

Use Asset Technical Clearing Account as Anchor since the GR/IR entry for asset acquisition always involves:

  • Dr: Asset Technical Clearing Account
  • Cr: GR/IR Account

You can filter FBL3N or build a custom report using:

  • GL Account = GR/IR Account
  • Document contains Asset Technical Clearing Account on the debit side

This helps isolate GR/IR entries tied to asset acquisition, excluding material/service receipts.

Cross-reference with Asset Master using table ANEK (Asset Document Header) and ANEP (Asset Line Items) to identify asset-related postings. Then match these with BKPF (Document Header) and BSEG (Line Items) where:

  • BSEG-HKONT = GR/IR Account
  • BSEG-HKONT (other line) = Asset Technical Clearing Account

If standard reports don’t suffice, build a query or ABAP logic by selecting documents from BKPF with:

  • Document Type = WE
  • Transaction Code = MIGO

Join with BSEG where one line is GR/IR Account (Cr) and another is Asset Technical Clearing Account (Dr). Optionally, link to ANEP to confirm asset involvement.

entry.title: Re: How to transfer amount from GL account in profit cent...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the classic ECC transaction 9KE0 (used for internal profit center postings) is not available. Instead, SAP has introduced new allocation mechanisms tailored for cloud architecture and compliance with the Universal Allocation Framework.

Although your customer feels that the “Manage Allocations” app isn’t what they need, it is actually the official replacement for 9KE0 in Public Cloud. Here's why:

  • Perform periodic allocations between profit centers, cost centers, or other dimensions.
  • Use allocation cycles to define sender/receiver relationships.
  • Support statistical and real postings.
  • Allow GL account-based allocations using allocation bases like fixed percentages or actual usage.

Alternative option is to use “Post General Journal Entries” app from where, manually post from one profit center to another using appropriate GL accounts. This requires careful configuration of profit center derivation and validation rules.

If the internal service is project-based, use Project Settlement apps. Allocate costs from one profit center to another via internal projects. More on this in SAP’s guide to Project Settlement in Public Cloud.

entry.title: Outbound Delivery Not Triggered After Partial Task Confirmation via ManageSiteLogisticsTaskIn
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I’m currently working on a use case where we aim to automate the creation of an outbound delivery based on an open Site Logistics Task, using the web services QuerySiteLogisticsTaskIn and ManageSiteLogisticsTaskIn.

Scenario:

  1. We run the Outbound Delivery Requests MDR, which creates tasks from the Delivery Proposal screen.

  2. We use the QuerySiteLogisticsTaskIn web service to retrieve relevant task information before confirmation.

  3. We then attempt to confirm a partial release via ManageSiteLogisticsTaskIn — for example, confirming 10 cases out of 20 for a specific Product ID with a given Batch ID.

The issue:
I expected the system to automatically generate an outbound delivery for the confirmed 10 cases, but no outbound delivery has been created so far.

SAP Support feedback:
We have already opened a similar case with SAP Support, and their conclusion was:

"After much deliberation and deep analysis, we can conclude that this web service (ManageSiteLogisticsTaskIn) is intended to support the creation of an outbound delivery only when the full quantity of the pick task is confirmed. The web service does not support creation of an outbound delivery for partially confirmed quantities.
Although the system allows you to manually generate multiple outbound deliveries for a single pick task using the Late Delivery Split functionality through the SAP User Interface, this feature is not supported through the web service.
This limitation exists because the web service is designed to create an outbound delivery only after full quantity confirmation and does not support automatic handling of late delivery split.
We have analyzed the technical feasibility of implementing this functionality via the web service, but it is currently not possible."

My questions to the community:

  1. Has anyone found a feasible workaround for this limitation?

  2. How can we best handle the remaining deviation of the open task (partial quantities) through automation if the standard web service does not support it?

I’ve attached a screenshots of the task for reference.

The payload request of ManageSiteLogisticsTaskIn:

The payload response of ManageSiteLogisticsTaskIn:

The result in SAP - partial confirm of 21186 task:

No outbound delivery for 4537 sales order after performing partial confirm for task 21186:

 

Thanks in advance for your guidance!

entry.title: Re: S4/HANA - How to develop an SAPUI5 app calling a back...
entry.content:
Developing an SAPUI5 application that communicates with backend logic in S/4HANA typically involves building a frontend UI in SAPUI5 and connecting it to an SAP backend system, such as SAP Gateway, OData services, or ABAP logic exposed as web services. Here’s a step-by-step guide on how to develop such an SAPUI5 app that calls backend logic:

1. Set Up the Backend System (S/4HANA)
Before you start developing the SAPUI5 application, you need to ensure that the backend logic is ready and accessible.

Expose OData Service
S/4HANA often exposes backend business logic through OData services. OData is a standardized protocol used for querying and updating data, and it works well with SAPUI5, which is optimized for OData-based communication.

Create/Use an Existing OData Service: You can either create a custom OData service in SAP Gateway (using SAP NetWeaver Gateway) or use an existing one (such as standard SAP business services).

Use ABAP Logic: If needed, ABAP logic can be encapsulated in a custom OData service or a REST service (depending on your business scenario).

To create or configure an OData service, you can use SEGW (Gateway Service Builder) in SAP to create a service and link it to an SAP backend.

Backend Logic (e.g., ABAP)
Develop the necessary backend logic in ABAP (e.g., function modules, BAPIs, or custom business logic).

Ensure that this logic is exposed through an OData service or RFC interface.

Once the service is created and activated, test it using SAP Gateway Client to ensure it's returning the expected data.

2. Develop the SAPUI5 Application
Now, let’s walk through how to build the frontend SAPUI5 application that will call the backend service.

Set Up SAPUI5 Project in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)
Create a New SAPUI5 Project:

In SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) or Eclipse with SAPUI5 Tools, create a new project using the SAP Fiori template.

Configure the Project for Backend Integration:

In the manifest.json file of your SAPUI5 project, define the connection to the OData service (or any other backend service). The dataSources section in manifest.json specifies the connection settings.

Example configuration for an OData service in the manifest.json:

entry.title: Invoking LLM from Cloud Integration Responsibly – Made Easy with Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core
entry.content:
In this blog post, I’ll walk you through how to seamlessly invoke large language models (LLMs) from Cloud Integration using the Generative AI Hub and the Orchestration Workflow API in SAP AI Core. We’ll focus on building a GDPR-compliant automation flow that leverages data masking and pseudonymisation to ensure privacy while still delivering value from generative AI.

The scenario we'll explore simulates a real-world use case: when a Business Partner record is updated in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, a personalized email notification is generated by an LLM and automatically sent out via Cloud Integration.

Thanks to prebuilt orchestration capabilities of Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, such as templating, I/O filtering, and data masking, the process of generating compliant LLM responses can be achieved with just a single API call.

 

Before diving into the implementation steps, let’s take a closer look at the process flow behind this sample scenario.

Process Flow (Steps)

  1. Business Partner Update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
    A user creates or edits a Business Partner record in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Event Triggered and Message Sent to SAP AEM
    The system triggers an event and sends a message to SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM).
  3. Cloud Integration iFlow Subscribes and Starts Processing
    The CPI iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and begins processing as soon as a new message is published.
  4. Retrieve Old Payload from CAP Application
    The iFlow queries the CAP application to retrieve the previous version (old payload) of the Business Partner record from SAP HANA Cloud.
  5. Call the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core for AI-Based Email Generation
    With both the old and new payloads in hand, the iFlow invokes the Generative AI Hub using the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core to generate a personalized email body in HTML format. Here, a predefined orchestration pipeline applies data masking, prompt templating, and foundation model invocation to generate a compliant, personalised email body – without exposing any sensitive data.
  6. Send Email to Business Partner
    The iFlow sends the generated email to the Business Partner’s email address via a standard mail adapter in Cloud Integration, completing the end-to-end notification process.

As part of this blog, I will not focus on connectivity between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Advanced Event Mesh (steps 1 and 2). For a live step-by-step demonstration of the setup, please review this video: 👉 SAP Tech Bytes: Configuring SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Configuring Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core

Orchestration in SAP AI Core is a managed service that enables unified access, control, and execution of generative AI models through standardized APIs, templating, and configurable AI workflow components.

In our scenario, we will utilize it to chain together prebuilt steps, such as data masking and foundation model invocation, to generate a personalized email body in HTML format via a single API call.

To access the Orchestration service in SAP AI Core, you need to set up Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad. Please refer to either of the following resources for setup instructions:

  • SAP Discovery Mission: Set Up SAP AI Core Generative AI Hub
  • SAP Developer Center Tutorial: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - Setup

Before moving to the next step, please ensure that your orchestration configuration is deployed and is in the RUNNING status.

Building the Orchestration Workflow

Within SAP AI Launchpad, navigate to Generative AI Hub -> Orchestration and click Edit Workflow to select the workflow steps you require.

For our scenario, deselect the Input Translation and Output Translation steps, as they are not needed.

In the Templating step, we define prompts that guide LLM on how to perform its task.

We configure two types of messages for our scenario:

  • System Prompt
  • User Prompt

The system prompt defines the overall behavior, tone, and role of the LLM. It sets global instructions that remain consistent across requests, ensuring predictable formatting and response style.

For our use case, the system prompt will instruct the LLM to act as a multilingual assistant that compares old and new Business Partner profiles and generates a compliant email.

You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".
Instructions:
- Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
- Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
- Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
- Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
- Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
- Do not generate the email subject line, only the body.

The user prompt provides the dynamic, task-specific input for each request. Here, we pass actual data: the old profile payload, new profile payload, and target language. These placeholders will be replaced at runtime to generate personalized content.

Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}
Here is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}
Here is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}

 

In the Data Masking step, we can anonymize or pseudonymize personally identifiable information from the input for selected entities. For our scenario, we will select the Pseudonymization option. This will substitute personally identifiable information in selected categories with a MASKED_ENTITY_ID placeholder and allow us to unmask the LLM response before returning it to the Sender.

The Input Filtering step allows you to apply content safety filters to the incoming data before invoking the foundation model.

In the Model Configuration step, we can select the desired model (e.g., GPT-4.1) and configure relevant parameters such as temperature, token limits, etc.

Finally, the Output Filtering step enables content safety filtering on the LLM-generated response to ensure compliance and prevent undesired content.

Once the orchestration workflow is configured, you can inspect its JSON definition and download it locally. This definition will be used later when invoking the orchestration workflow via API from Cloud Integration.

Additionally, you can test the orchestration inference directly within SAP AI Launchpad by providing sample input variables. The testing tool allows you to view and trace the LLM response and fine-tune the workflow configuration as needed.

When inspecting the output payload, you can clearly trace the results of each orchestration step – such as Input Masking, Output Unmasking, Input Filtering, and Output Filtering.

To learn more about Orchestration in SAP AI Core, refer to the SAP Developer Center Tutorials: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - orchestration.

Configure SAP Cloud Integration Business Partner Notification iFlow

Now that we have our SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, and the Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core configured, we can proceed with the Cloud Integration iFlow configuration.

This iFlow ensures that Business Partner changes trigger compliant AI-generated email notifications, while maintaining data consistency in HANA Cloud. It leverages SAP Advanced Event Mesh, CAP, and Generative AI Hub for an automated end-to-end process.

High-Level iFlow Overview

  • Triggered by AEM Queue when a new event is published.
  • Retrieves BP details from S/4HANA Cloud.
  • (If event is BP update) Fetches old BP payload from HANA Cloud (via CAP service).
  • Invokes the Orchestration Workflow API to compare old vs. new payloads and generate an HTML email content while ensuring that no sensitive information is passed to LLM.
  • Upserts updated BP details into SAP HANA Cloud via CAP service.
  • Sends an email to the Business Partner.

Step-by-Step Process Breakdown

  1. Event Trigger
    • The iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and processes incoming events.
  2. Retrieve Business Partner Details
    • An OData request is sent to SAP S/4HANA Cloud to fetch the latest BP details.
    • Key parameters (e.g., BP ID, BP email) are extracted and saved into the properties for further processing.
  3. Map to CAP Format
    • BP details are transformed into the CAP service data model.
    • The new payload is stored in XML and JSON format for further use.
  4. Conditional Logic
    • BP creation → No old payload is retrieved.
    • BP update → Old payload is retrieved for comparison.
  5. Retrieve Old Payload from HANA Cloud (BP update only)
    • The iFlow calls the CAP service to fetch the previous BP record. Please refer to the GitHub repository businesspartner_srv for more information on the CAP service. In our scenario, the CAP service acts as an intermediary that retrieves old Business Partner data from SAP HANA Cloud, provides an OData service for data access, and enables the upsert of updated details.
  6. AI-Based Email Generation
    • A subprocess calls the Orchestration Workflow API via the AI adapter to create a personalized HTML email body in a GDPR-compliant way.
  7. Upsert BP Details in HANA Cloud
    • The updated BP details are upserted into SAP HANA Cloud via the CAP service.
  8. Send Email
    • The iFlow sends an email using the Mail Adapter.

You can find this iFlow as a ZIP archive here: AEM_GenAI_BPMailGenerator_blog.zip

For this blog, we’ll take a closer look at Step #6, where the AI Receiver Adapter is used to invoke the Orchestration Workflow API configured in the previous section.

1) In our case, the easiest way to prepare a payload for the AI Receiver Adapter is by using a small Groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

Message processData(Message message) {
    def map = message.getProperties()

    // Get values from properties
    def language = map.get("language")
    def oldPayload = map.get("old_payload_json")
    def newPayload = map.get("new_payload_json")

    // Build the JSON structure
    def payload = [
        orchestration_config: [
            module_configurations: [
                llm_module_config: [
                    model_name: "gpt-4.1",
                    model_params: [
                        frequency_penalty: 0,
                        presence_penalty: 0,
                        max_completion_tokens: 24576,
                        temperature: 1
                    ],
                    model_version: "2025-04-14"
                ],
                templating_module_config: [
                    template: [
                        [
                            role: "user",
                            content: [
                                [
                                    type : "text",
                                    text : "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"
                                ]
                            ]
                        ],
                        [
                            role: "system",
                            content: [
                                [
                                    type : "text",
                                    text : """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".

Instructions:
- Detect all changes.
- Summarize them clearly.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Don't generate the subject, only the email body.
- Format it as an HTML (NO code blocks like ```html).
- Ignore change_time change_date changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- Include a friendly closing.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center."""
                                ]
                            ]
                        ]
                    ],
                    defaults: [:]
                ],
                filtering_module_config: [
                input : [
                    filters: [
                        [
                            type: "azure_content_safety",
                            config: [
                                Hate: 2,
                                SelfHarm: 2,
                                Sexual: 2,
                                Violence: 2,
                                PromptShield: true
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ],
                output: [
                    filters: [
                        [
                            type  : "azure_content_safety",
                            config: [
                                Hate: 2,
                                SelfHarm: 2,
                                Sexual: 2,
                                Violence: 2
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            ],
                masking_module_config: [
                    masking_providers: [
                        [
                            type: "sap_data_privacy_integration",
                            method: "pseudonymization",
                            entities: [
                                [type: "profile-credit-card-number"],
                                [type: "profile-driverlicense"],
                                [type: "profile-email"],
                                [type: "profile-sensitive-data"],
                                [type: "profile-ethnicity"],
                                [type: "profile-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-pronouns-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-iban"],
                                [type: "profile-location"],
                                [type: "profile-nationalid"],
                                [type: "profile-nationality"],
                                [type: "profile-org"],
                                [type: "profile-passport"],
                                [type: "profile-person"],
                                [type: "profile-phone"],
                                [type: "profile-political-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-public"],
                                [type: "profile-religious-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-internal"],
                                [type: "profile-ssn"],
                                [type: "profile-sexual-orientation"],
                                [type: "profile-trade-union"],
                                [type: "profile-address"],
                                [type: "profile-url"],
                                [type: "profile-university"],
                                [type: "profile-username-password"]
                            ],
                            mask_grounding_input: [enabled: false],
                            allowlist: []
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            ]
        ],
        input_params: [
            language_name: language,
            old_payload: oldPayload instanceof String ? oldPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(oldPayload),
            new_payload: newPayload instanceof String ? newPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(newPayload)
        ]
    ]

    // Serialize to JSON string
    def jsonString = JsonOutput.toJson(payload)
    message.setBody(jsonString)

    return message
}
​

This script constructs the payload expected by the Orchestration API of SAP AI Core.

Note that the settings within the module_configurations block match the configuration that you downloaded from SAP AI Launchpad.

2) To set up a Connection to our AI Core Orchestration deployment, we first need to configure a Security Material.
In your SAP BTP Cockpit and access the service key of the SAP AI Core (extended plan) service instance created earlier.

Create an OAuth2 Client Credentials Security Material with:

  • Token Service URL: url from the service key + “/oauth/token”
  • Client ID: clientid from the service key
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from the service key

On the Connection tab of the AI Receiver Adapter:

  • Set the Address to the AI_API_URL from the service key.
  • Reference the Security Material in the OAuth2 Client Credentials field.

On the Processing tab:

  • Set Request Payload Source to “Exchange Body”.
  • Provide the Orchestration Deployment ID and AI Resource Group from SAP AI Launchpad.

3) JSON output is converted into XML for further processing.

4) Content Modifier step is used to extract the email_body from the Orchestration API response via the XPath expression: /root/orchestration_result/choices/message/content

Testing the Scenario End-to-End

With all components configured, it’s time to put the setup to the test.

📽️ Watch Event-Driven Business Partner Email Notification Demo 

The video walks through the entire process – showing the change in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the processing inside Cloud Integration, and the final email received by the Business Partner.

Conclusion

This scenario highlights how simple and seamless it is to invoke SAP AI Core from Cloud Integration to generate compliant, human-sounding content.

With just a small Groovy script to prepare the payload, CPI can call an SAP AI Core Orchestration Workflow directly via the AI Receiver Adapter – without complex custom coding or middleware. All compliance safeguards, such as data masking and filtering, are handled by the orchestration workflow, ensuring that no sensitive information is ever sent to the LLM.

The result is an automated, end-to-end process where a Business Partner update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud triggers an event, CPI processes it, SAP AI Core generates the compliant email body, and the recipient is informed – all with minimal configuration effort.

This pattern can be applied to other master data objects and backend systems, as well as to any scenario where Cloud Integration must securely generate AI-based content — making it a powerful blueprint for scaling compliant AI adoption across the enterprise.

entry.title: Re: Change EKET - EINDT as a collectively
entry.content:
The standard approach would be to use Transaction ME38 from where you can mass update delivery dates for multiple items. Navigate to the schedule lines and change EINDT directly.

If you're working with purchase orders, go to ME22N, use the “Collective Processing” or “Mass Change” options. Select multiple items and update the delivery date (EINDT) in one go.

If standard transactions don’t meet your needs, you can use BAPI_PO_CHANGE: For purchase orders

Finally and most importantly, SAP may override EINDT values based on delivery schedules, MRP, or vendor confirmations. So test thoroughly in QA system before applying in production.

entry.title: Re: DI API Problem Class COM with SAP Business One Applic...
entry.content:
I just noticed that the article is in French and it is not possible to copy the text, so I leave you the solution here in English

 

Diagnostic:

⚠️ This behavior is known — Technical explanation
The DI API (COM) registers through CLSIDs in the Windows registry.
When both versions (32-bit and 64-bit) are installed, Windows may point the COM class to the wrong version because:

  • The COM registry (HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID) does not always correctly differentiate between 32-bit and 64-bit.

  • Some GUIDs may be overwritten or shared between the two versions.
    This is a COM registration conflict issue between the two architectures.

Recommended Solution: Isolate or Force the COM Architecture Used

 Avoid COM Registration Conflicts

a. Use a tool like RegSvr32 with the /regserver option to manually re-register the 64-bit DI API after installing the 32-bit version.

 
C:\Windows\System32\regsvr32.exe "C:\Program Files\SAP\SAP Business One DI API\SAPbobsCOM.dll"

This forces the 64-bit COM registration, even if the 32-bit version is also installed.

You can also run the following in CMD:

 
C:\Windows\SysWOW64\regsvr32.exe "C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP\SAP Business One DI API\DI API xx\SAPbobsCOMxx.dll"

(Here, xx represents the version number of the file — this is for re-registering the 32-bit version.)

Important:
Always ensure the correct version is registered for the application in use.

Hello Gergo,
Thank you for your reply.
Yes, most SAP notes are client-independent, but it would be cleaner if the transport layers were unique.
We usually generate transports from the PFCG, but in some cases, roles are also assigned to the transport as objects via lists. For transport layers, the transport system checks the correctness of the transport routes, so it would be nice to be able to define name-specific rules for this.
I would like to eliminate sources of error as far as possible.

To achieve automatic tax code selection in Purchase Orders based on vendor region in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, you’ll need to implement a custom validation or enhancement, as standard SAP does not dynamically restrict tax codes based on region


Create a custom table as under

You can have as many entries in the table depending upon the Business requirement.  You can implement this logic logic in user exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_012 or BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST. Use this table in your enhancement to validate tax code selection.
